bioghist.p: The Pennsylvania Nautical School was formed in 1889 by the Pennsylvania State Legislature to fulfill the nation's demand for trained seamen. For 58 years cadets were instructed by U.S. Navy officers in the arts of navigation, marine engineering and seamanship to prepare them for careers in the maritime trades and professions. In 1942 the school was renamed Pennsylvania Maritime Academy (based in Morrisville, Pennsylvania) and in 1947 the Academy closed. Between 1889 and 1947, close to 2000 cadets graduated from the program. The Alumni Association was formed in 1955 and publishes two periodicals: The Lookout and The Chronicle. Ships retired from the Navy were retrofitted into schoolships. The Nautical School taught aboard seven different ships over its 58 year history: Sloop-of-War USS Saratoga (1889-1907); Cruiser USS Adams (1907-1914); Gunboat USS Annapolis (1919-1942); Light Cruiser USS Omaha (1940); Ammunition Ship USS Pyro (1940); Cutter USS Keystone State, ex Seneca (1942-1946); and Attack Cargo Ship USS Keystone State II, ex. USS Selinur (1946-1947).

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers related to the Pennsylvania Nautical School and the Pennsylvania Nautical Schoolship Association, the Nautical School's alumni association. Files on cadets include: photographs; correspondence from cadets to their families and from the school to families; itineraries; grade sheets; programs; diaries; newspaper clippings; and ephemera. Files on ships include: photographs, negatives, and other images of ship layouts. General school materials include: course materials from the Densmore textbook on various aspects of nautical engineering; newspaper clippings; an 1889 prospectus for the school; diplomas and certificates; copies of The Helm (1924-1946); and copies of The Log of the Pennsylvania Nautical School and The Log of the American Merchant Training Ships (1912-1915). Among the PNS files, a number of items are present as photocopies. Material related to the Schoolship Association includes: invitations and programs from Association events; memorials; directories; a 50th anniversary booklet; copies of The Lookout (1956-2006) and The Chronicle; and a drawing of USS Annapolis. Also included in the collection are a 1795 copy of the Naval Gazetteer, a 1859 bible presented to H. Brower, and a set of 1989 drawings of the Steam Tug Hercules from the San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
